title: Modules
text:
Module 1: Foundations of Open Science
Weeks: 1–4
Guiding questions: What is open science, why has it emerged, and how does it relate to reproducibility?

Weekly Breakdown
Week 1 – What is Open Science?
- Topics: History and motivations, open vs. closed research, myths about openness.
- Activities: Discussion of exemplar open projects, short diagnostic survey on prior experience.
- Suggested Deliverable: Reflection on your current research workflow.
Week 2 – The Reproducibility Crisis
- Topics: Replication failures, methodological reforms, preregistration and registered reports.
- Activities: Reading discussion on replication case studies, in-class critique of a methods section.
- Suggested Deliverable: Reflection 1 (reproducibility in your field).
Week 3 – Frameworks and Standards
- Topics: FAIR principles, TOP guidelines, data and code availability statements.
- Activities: Group mapping of a research project to FAIR and TOP, discussion of journal policies.
- Suggested Deliverable: Short memo identifying a target journal’s openness policies.
Week 4 – Research Workflows and Project Structure
- Topics: Folder organization, naming conventions, documentation as part of the workflow.
- Activities: Walkthrough of a well-organized open project repository.
- Graded Deliverable: Lab 1 – Project skeleton (directories, README, basic documentation).

title: Modules
text:
Module 2: Tools for Reproducible Research
Weeks: 5–8
Guiding questions: How can we use tools to make our work traceable, repeatable, and automatable?

Weekly Breakdown
Week 5 – Version Control with Git
- Topics: Commits, branches, merging, working locally with Git.
- Activities: Live demo of Git basics, practice committing and reverting changes.
- Graded Deliverable: Lab 2 – Git basics (initialize repo, commit history, branching exercise).
Week 6 – GitHub for Collaboration
- Topics: Remote repositories, pull requests, issues, project boards.
- Activities: Pair activity using pull requests and code review; setting up a course organization or team.
- Suggested Deliverable: Reflection 2 (collaboration norms and practices).
Week 7 – Literate Programming with Quarto
- Topics: Quarto documents, parameters, rendering to HTML/PDF, reproducible reports.
- Activities: Build a simple analysis report from data import to figure and narrative.
- Graded Deliverable: Lab 3 – Reproducible report (Quarto document with code and narrative).
Week 8 – Data Management and Documentation
- Topics: Tidy data, metadata, README files, data dictionaries.
- Activities: Critique and improve an example dataset and its documentation.
- Graded Deliverable: Data & code checklist for your project.

title: Modules
text:
Module 3: Sharing, Collaboration, and Openness
Weeks: 9–11
Guiding questions: How do we share our work responsibly and effectively so that others can reuse and build on it?

Weekly Breakdown
Week 9 – Sharing Data and Code
- Topics: Repositories (GitHub, OSF, Zenodo), DOIs, versioned releases.
- Activities: Evaluate different repository platforms for a sample project.
- Suggested Deliverable: Reflection 3 (where and how you will share your work).
Week 10 – Licensing and Attribution
- Topics: Creative Commons licenses, software licenses (MIT, GPL, etc.), citation and credit.
- Activities: License selection exercise for sample projects and materials.
- Graded Deliverable: Lab 4 – Licensing plan for your open project.
Week 11 – Open Peer Review and Feedback
- Topics: Peer review models, open reports, constructive feedback practices.
- Activities: In-class peer review workshop using project drafts.
- Graded Deliverable: Peer review of a classmate’s repository and report.

title: Modules
section: Module 4: Applications, Ethics, and Project Synthesis
text:
Module 4: Applications, Ethics, and Project Synthesis
Weeks: 12–14
Guiding questions: How can open science be practiced ethically and equitably, and how will you apply it in your own work?

Weekly Breakdown
Week 12 – Ethics, Equity, and Inclusion in Open Science
- Topics: Power and access, data justice, risks of openness, community-engaged research.
- Activities: Case study discussions on ethical dilemmas in sharing data and code.
- Suggested Deliverable: Reflection 4 (ethical considerations in your project).
Week 13 – Open Science in Practice
- Topics: Case studies across disciplines, institutional and funder policies, career implications.
- Activities: Guest speaker(s), panel discussion, project troubleshooting clinic.
- Graded Deliverable: Lab 5 – Project refinement checklist and action plan.
Week 14 – Project Presentations and Course Reflection
- Topics: Communicating your open project, lessons learned, next steps.
- Activities: Short presentations or lightning talks; group reflection on open science practices.
- Graded Deliverable: Final open project due (repository, documentation, and rendered report/site).

title: Module 3
text:
Module 3 centers on sharing your research outputs, collaborating in the open, and building practices that enable others to reuse and extend your work. Over three weeks, you will explore platforms, licensing, and peer review models that support open and participatory science.

Weeks: 9–11

Guiding questions:

How can we share data, code, and materials so they are genuinely reusable?

What roles do licenses and attribution play in open scholarship?

How can peer review become more transparent, constructive, and collaborative?

title: Module 3
text:
Week 9 – Sharing Data and Code
Focus: Platforms and practices for making research products accessible and citable.

Topics:

Types of repositories: GitHub, OSF, Zenodo, institutional repositories.
Releases, DOIs, and versioned snapshots.
Minimum information for reuse (data + code + documentation).

In-class activities:

Compare repository platforms using a simple rubric (features, cost, longevity, ease of use).
Examine examples of “good” and “less good” shared projects and discuss what makes them reusable.

Suggested deliverable:

Reflection 3 – Sharing Data and Code
Discuss opportunities and constraints for sharing in your field, including sensitive data, proprietary tools, or institutional policies.

Suggested preparation:

Identify at least one repository that is common in your discipline.
Bring an example of a shared dataset or codebase you admire (or find confusing).

title: Module 3
text:
Week 10 – Licensing and Attribution
Focus: Legal and ethical frameworks for reuse and credit.

Topics:

Overview of Creative Commons licenses (e.g., CC BY, CC BY-SA, CC BY-NC) and public‑domain tools.
Software licenses (e.g., MIT, GPL, Apache) and how they differ from CC licenses.
Attribution practices, citation of data and code, and credit beyond authorship.

In-class activities:

License selection exercise for several hypothetical projects (e.g., teaching materials, software, datasets).
Analyze license choices in real open projects and discuss their implications.

Graded deliverable:

Lab 4 – Licensing Plan
Propose and implement a licensing strategy for your open project, including:

A license for code.

A license for text and teaching materials.

A short rationale documented in your repository.


Suggested preparation:

Review institutional or funder guidance on sharing and licensing, if available.
Note any collaborators or stakeholders who might influence your licensing decisions.

title: Module 3
section: Week 11 – Open Peer Review and Feedback
text:
Week 11 – Open Peer Review and Feedback
Focus: Making peer review more transparent, constructive, and educational.

Topics:

Traditional vs. open peer review models (signed, anonymous, published reports).
Principles of constructive feedback and reviewer responsibilities.
Using issues, pull requests, and comments as review mechan

title: Module 4
text:
Module 4 synthesizes the course by applying open science practices across disciplines, addressing ethical considerations, and completing your open project for public sharing. Over three weeks, you will refine your work, present it to peers, and reflect on how to sustain these practices long-term.

Weeks: 12–14

Guiding questions:

What are the ethical, equity, and inclusion challenges of open science?

How is open science practiced across different fields and contexts?

How will you carry open practices forward in your own work?

title: Module 4
section: Week 12 – Ethics, Equity, and Inclusion in Open Science
text:
Week 12 – Ethics, Equity, and Inclusion in Open Science
Focus: Responsible and inclusive practices beyond technical implementation.

Topics:

Data justice, privacy, and harms of over-sharing sensitive information.
Power dynamics, access barriers, and the digital divide in open scholarship.
Community-engaged research, citizen science, and participatory openness.

In-class activities:

Case study discussions of ethical dilemmas in data/code sharing.
Group brainstorming of inclusive practices for documentation and collaboration.

Suggested deliverable:

Reflection 4 – Ethics and Equity
Consider ethical and equity implications of openness for the communities, data, or contexts in your project.

Suggested preparation:

Review your project through an ethics lens: what data are you sharing, with whom, and under what terms?

title: Module 4
text:
Week 13 – Open Science in Practice
Focus: Real-world applications and sustainability.

Topics:

Disciplinary case studies and open science success stories.
Institutional policies, funder mandates, and career implications.
Long-term sustainability: archiving, maintenance, and community contributions.

In-class activities:

Guest speaker(s) or panel on open science in practice.
Project troubleshooting clinic and final polish workshop.
Discussion of next steps for students’ projects post-course.

Graded deliverable:

Lab 5 – Project Refinement
Complete a self-audit checklist and implement improvements for organization, documentation, reproducibility, and presentation readiness.

Suggested preparation:

Run a “stranger test”: can someone unfamiliar with your project reproduce key results?

title: Module 4
section: Week 14 – Project Presentations and Course Reflection
text:
Week 14 – Project Presentations and Course Reflection
Focus: Sharing your work and synthesizing course learning.

Topics:

Effective communication of open projects (READMEs, talks, write-ups).
Lessons learned and future directions for open science practice.
Course retrospective and peer feedback on final projects.

In-class activities:

Student presentations (5–10 minutes each): project overview, workflow, key findings, openness features.
Group discussion: what surprised you, what will you change, what needs more work?

Graded deliverable:

Final Open Project (repository + presentation)
Public GitHub repository with complete documentation, reproducible analysis/report/site, appropriate licensing, and evidence of peer review integration.

title: Module 4
text:
Course Synthesis
Module 4 completes the progression from concepts → tools → sharing → responsible practice:
By now, you should have: - A public, documented, reproducible project that demonstrates open science principles. - Experience with the full workflow: planning, coding, collaborating, reviewing, sharing, and reflecting. - A personal framework for evaluating and improving openness in future work.

title: Module 4
text:
Next Steps Beyond the Course

Maintain your project repository as a portfolio piece or living analysis.
Apply these practices to your thesis, publications, or collaborations.
Contribute to open science communities through code, feedback, or teaching others.
Stay connected via course GitHub organization or open science networks in your field.

title: Introduction to Open Science
text: This course introduces students to open science – a set of principles and practices aimed at making scientific research processes and outputs as accessible, transparent, and reusable as possible for both researchers and the wider public. Students will explore how openness enhances reproducibility, transparency, and collaboration in modern research across disciplines. Emphasis is placed on practical application—learning by doing through open source tools, reproducible workflows, and shared research artifacts.

Learning Objectives

Explain the foundations and rationale of the open science movement.

Evaluate ethical, equitable, and inclusive challenges in open scholarship.

Develop a reproducible mini-project using open science workflows.

text:
Grading Breakdown

title: Assignments
text:
Participation and Engagement (10%)
Participation includes:

Regular attendance and preparation (completing readings or short pre-class tasks).

Active, respectful engagement in discussions, peer review, and in-class activities.

Contributions to collaborative workspaces (e.g., GitHub Discussions, shared notes).

Participation is assessed holistically across the semester rather than on a point-per-day basis.

title: Assignments
text:
Reflections (20%)
You will complete four short reflections (about 500 words each). Each reflection asks you to connect course ideas to your own disciplinary context or research interests.

Reflection 1 – Reproducibility in your field (Week 2):
Describe how reproducibility issues show up in your discipline and what reforms you see (or don’t see).
Reflection 2 – Collaboration and version control (Week 6):
Reflect on how Git/GitHub could change the way you collaborate on research or teaching.
Reflection 3 – Sharing data and code (Week 9):
Discuss opportunities and challenges for sharing data/code in your area, including any constraints.
Reflection 4 – Ethics, equity, and openness (Week 12):
Consider ethical and equity implications of open science for the communities and contexts you study.

Each reflection is typically submitted via the course repo (e.g., a Markdown or Quarto file in your student folder) with a short commit message.

title: Assignments
text:
Labs / Practical Exercises (30%)
Labs are structured, hands-on activities that build specific skills. Each is designed to be small enough for 1–2 weeks of work.

Lab 1 – Project Skeleton (Week 4)

Set up a logically organized project structure (folders for data, code, docs, outputs).

Create a README that describes the project purpose, data sources (real or simulated), and basic instructions.

Add minimal documentation (e.g., placeholder data dictionary, notes on required software).

Deliverable: A Git-tracked project skeleton in your repository, with initial commit history.



Lab 2 – Git Basics (Week 5)

Initialize a local Git repository or connect to an existing remote.

Practice staging, committing, viewing history, and creating/merging branches.

Demonstrate at least one example of resolving a simple conflict or reverting changes.

Deliverable: Repository with clear commit history that documents your work across multiple commits.



Lab 3 – Reproducible Report with Quarto (Week 7)

Create a Quarto document that imports data, performs a simple analysis, and produces at least one figure or table.

Include narrative text interpreting results, plus a short “Methods” description.

Ensure the document can be rendered from raw data to final output with a single command.

Deliverable: Quarto source file and rendered output (HTML or PDF) in your repository.



Lab 4 – Licensing Plan (Week 10)

Identify appropriate licenses for your project’s code and content (e.g., MIT for code, CC BY for materials).

Add license information to your repository (e.g., LICENSE and CONTENT-LICENSE files, plus notes in the README).

Briefly justify your choices in a short Markdown/Quarto note.

Deliverable: Updated repository with licenses in place and a one-page licensing rationale.



Lab 5 – Project Refinement (Week 13)

Conduct a self-audit of your project using a provided checklist (organization, documentation, reproducibility).

Address at least three concrete improvements (e.g., clearer file naming, more detailed README, improved comments).

Prepare your repository for public sharing and final presentation.

Deliverable: Updated repository and completed checklist summarizing changes made.

title: Assignments
text:
Open Project (40%)
The open project is a small, self-contained research or demonstration project that applies the concepts and tools from the course. You may work individually or in pairs (with instructor approval).

Components and Timeline

Project Idea / Proposal (5%) – around Week 5–6

1–2 pages outlining your research question or demonstration goal, data source(s), planned methods, and openness plan.

Project Draft (10%) – around Week 10–11

Working repository with initial analysis, draft Quarto report or site, and preliminary documentation.

Used for in-class peer review.

Final Project (20%) – Week 14

Public GitHub repository with:

Organized folder structure and clear README.

Data (or clear description and access instructions), code, and fully rendered report/site.

Licensing and citation information.

Evidence that the workflow is reproducible on another machine (within reasonable constraints).


Presentation (5%) – Week 14

5–10 minute in-class presentation or lightning talk.

Briefly describe the research question, workflow, key findings, and how you implemented open and reproducible practices.




Evaluation Criteria
Projects are evaluated on:

Reproducibility: Can others follow your instructions and re-run the analysis?

Openness: Are data, code, and materials shared with appropriate licensing and documentation?

Rigor and clarity: Are methods and results communicated clearly and accurately?

Design and organization: Is the repository easy to navigate and understand?

Reflection: Do you thoughtfully discuss limitations, ethical considerations, and next steps?

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Description
This course introduces the principles and practices of open science, with an emphasis on reproducible research workflows, transparent reporting, and collaborative scholarship. Students will critically examine the reproducibility crisis, explore tools that support openness (such as Git, GitHub, and Quarto), and apply these tools in hands-on assignments and a final open project.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Describe key concepts in open science, including transparency, reproducibility, and open scholarship.

Use version control and hosted repositories to manage research projects collaboratively.

Create reproducible analyses and reports using scripted workflows and literate programming tools.

Apply best practices for sharing data, code, and other research outputs with appropriate documentation.

Critically evaluate ethical, legal, and equity considerations in open science.

title: Syllabus
text:
Open Project Requirements
Your open project should:

Live in a public GitHub repository under your account (or a course organization).

Include a clear README describing the project, requirements, and how to reproduce results.

Provide data (or simulated/open data), code, and a rendered report or site.

Use an appropriate license for code and content, documented in the repository.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Policies

Attendance and Participation
Active participation is essential to developing practical open science skills. More than a specified number of unexcused absences (define this in your local context) may affect your participation grade.


Late Work
Specify your policy here, such as a percentage deduction per day late up to a maximum, or acceptance only by prior arrangement. Clarify how this applies to labs, reflections, and the final project.


Academic Integrity
All work must comply with institutional policies on academic integrity. When reusing or adapting open materials, you must provide proper attribution and follow the terms of the original licenses.


Accessibility and Accommodations
Students requiring accommodations are encouraged to contact the instructor and the campus accessibility office as early as possible to ensure appropriate arrangements.


Technology and Data Ethics
Students are expected to follow ethical and legal guidelines in handling data. When using real-world datasets, ensure that data use complies with privacy and institutional or IRB policies where applicable.

title: Module 2
text:
Module 2 focuses on concrete tools and workflows that make research more reproducible, transparent, and collaborative. Over four weeks, you will learn to use Git, GitHub, and Quarto, and to organize data and documentation so others can reliably rerun your work.

Weeks: 5–8

Guiding questions:

How can version control support transparent, collaborative research?

What does a reproducible computational workflow look like in practice?

How should we structure and document data, code, and outputs?

title: Module 2
text:
Module 2 focuses on concrete tools and workflows that make research more reproducible, transparent, and collaborative. Over four weeks, you will learn to use Git, GitHub, and Quarto, and to organize data and documentation so others can reliably rerun your work.

Weeks: 5–8

Guiding questions:

How can version control support transparent, collaborative research?

What does a reproducible computational workflow look like in practice?

How should we structure and document data, code, and outputs?

title: Module 2
text:
Week 5 – Version Control with Git
Focus: Local version control for research projects.

Topics:

Core Git concepts: repositories, commits, history, branches.
Working locally: staging changes, committing, inspecting logs.
Good commit messages and incremental development.

In-class activities:

Live demo of basic Git commands in a small project.
Hands-on practice: making edits, staging, committing, viewing history.

Graded deliverable:

Lab 2 – Git Basics
Initialize (or continue) a Git repository for your project, demonstrate meaningful commit history, and practice simple branching and merging.

Suggested preparation:

Install Git and configure your username and email.
Skim a short intro guide to Git concepts and terminology.

title: Module 2
text:
Week 6 – GitHub for Collaboration
Focus: Moving from local Git to hosted repositories and collaboration.

Topics:

Remotes, pushing and pulling between local and GitHub.
Forks, pull requests, and basic review workflows.
Using issues and project boards to manage tasks.

In-class activities:

Pair or small-group exercise using pull requests and code review comments.
Setting up or joining a GitHub organization or team for the course (if applicable).

Suggested deliverable:

Reflection 2 – Collaboration and Version Control
Reflect on how Git/GitHub could change your collaborative practices in research or teaching.

Suggested preparation:

Create a GitHub account (if you don’t have one).
Connect your local Git configuration to GitHub via HTTPS or SSH.

title: Module 2
text:
Week 7 – Literate Programming with Quarto
Focus: Combining code, narrative, and outputs in a single, reproducible document.

Topics:

Structure of a Quarto document: YAML front matter, code chunks, text.
Rendering to multiple formats (HTML, PDF, etc.).
Managing dependencies (packages, data paths) for reproducibility.

In-class activities:

Build a simple end-to-end report: data import, basic analysis, figure, and interpretation.
Explore examples of well-documented Quarto reports and sites.

Graded deliverable:

Lab 3 – Reproducible Report
Create a Quarto document that reads data, performs a simple analysis, and produces at least one figure or table, with clear narrative explaining methods and results.

Suggested preparation:

Install Quarto and confirm it works with your preferred environment (e.g., RStudio, VS Code).
Review a short tutorial on Quarto syntax and rendering.

title: Module 2
text:
Week 8 – Data Management and Documentation
Focus: Organizing data and writing documentation that supports reuse.

Topics:

Tidy data principles and file naming conventions.
Metadata, data dictionaries, and codebooks.
Project-level documentation: README files and contribution notes.

In-class activities:

Critique and improve the structure and documentation of a sample dataset and repository.
Apply a data documentation checklist to your own project.

Graded deliverable:

Data & Code Checklist
Complete a checklist evaluating the organization and documentation of your project’s data and code, and implement at least one improvement.

Suggested preparation:

Review example README files and data dictionaries from open projects.
Identify the current state of your own project’s data and documentation.

title: Module 2
text:
Connecting to the Open Project
Module 2 provides the technical backbone for your open project:

Your Git/GitHub setup will track the evolution of your project and support collaboration.

Your Quarto report or site will serve as the primary, reproducible narrative of your work.

Your data management and documentation choices will determine how easily others can understand and reuse your materials.

The tools and habits you develop here will be revisited and extended in later modules as you share your work more broadly and consider licensing, ethics, and long-term sustainability.

title: Module 1
text:
Module 1 introduces the foundations of open science and the reproducibility movement. Across four weeks, you will explore key concepts, historical context, and practical frameworks that shape contemporary open and reproducible research.

Weeks: 1–4

What is open science and why does it matter?

title: Module 1
text:
Module 1 introduces the foundations of open science and the reproducibility movement. Across four weeks, you will explore key concepts, historical context, and practical frameworks that shape contemporary open and reproducible research.

Weeks: 1–4

Guiding questions:

What is open science and why does it matter?

How did the reproducibility crisis emerge?

What frameworks guide more transparent and reliable research?

title: Module 1
text:
Week 1 – What is Open Science?
Focus: History, definitions, and motivations.

Topics:

Historical roots of openness in scholarship.
Definitions of open science and related terms (open data, open code, open access).
Common myths and misconceptions about openness.

In-class activities:

Discussion of exemplar open projects from different disciplines.
Short diagnostic survey on students’ prior experience with open tools and practices.

Suggested preparation:

Read short overview pieces on open science and reproducibility (posted on the course site).
Reflect on how you currently share or do not share your work.

Suggested deliverable:

Brief reflection (informal) on your current research or study workflow and where it is “closed” or “open.”

title: Module 1
text:
Week 2 – The Reproducibility Crisis
Focus: Replication failures and reform movements.

Topics:

High-profile replication failures and their consequences.
Distinguishing reproducibility, replicability, and robustness.
Reform efforts: preregistration, registered reports, open materials.

In-class activities:

Reading discussion on one or more replication case studies.
Small-group critique of the methods section of a published paper.

Graded deliverable:

Reflection 1 – Reproducibility in your field
About 500 words on how reproducibility issues appear (or might appear) in your discipline and what changes you observe.

title: Module 1
section: Week 3 – Frameworks and Standards for Openness
text:
Week 3 – Frameworks and Standards for Openness
Focus: Principles and policies that structure open research.

Topics:

FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable).
TOP guidelines and journal policies on transparency.
Data and code availability statements.

In-class activities:

Group mapping of a sample research project to FAIR and TOP.
Review of journal policies relevant to students’ disciplines.

Suggested deliverable:

Short memo identifying a target journal or venue and summarizing its openness requirements (data, code, preregistration, etc.).

title: Module 1
section: Week 4 – Research Workflows and Project Structure
text:
Week 4 – Research Workflows and Project Structure
Focus: Organizing research projects for clarity and reproducibility.

Topics:

Folder organization, naming conventions, and file versioning.
Writing effective README files and basic documentation.
Thinking ahead to automation and scripted workflows.

In-class activities:

Walkthrough of a well-organized open project repository.
Hands-on practice sketching a project structure for the course open project.

Graded deliverable:

Lab 1 – Project Skeleton
Create a Git-tracked project structure with logical directories (e.g., data/, code/, docs/, outputs/) and an initial README that describes the project, data source(s), and basic instructions.

title: Module 1
text:
Looking Ahead
Module 1 lays the conceptual groundwork for the more technical modules that follow. In Module 2, you will begin working directly with version control (Git), GitHub, and Quarto to implement reproducible workflows using the project skeleton you build here.
